docs.title: Plated
docs.text:
Modern recipe management for your kitchen.

Plated is a Django-based web application for organizing, creating, and managing your recipes. Built with simplicity and usability in mind.

docs.title: Screenshots
docs.text:
DesktopTabletMobile

Plated on desktop - full recipe browsing experience

Plated on tablet - responsive layout adapts to medium screens

Plated on mobile - optimized for on-the-go cooking

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Recipe Management - Create, edit, and organize recipes with ingredients, steps, and images
  • Collections - Group related recipes together
  • Smart Input - Autocomplete for ingredient names and units to maintain consistency
  • Import/Export - JSON-based recipe data exchange
  • PDF Generation - Export recipes to beautifully formatted PDFs using Typst
  • Mobile-Friendly - Responsive design works on all devices
  • Dark Mode - Multiple color themes including dark mode
  • Internationalization - Support for multiple languages
  • AI Extraction - Extract recipe data from URLs using AI

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Choose your installation method:

  • Native Installation - Install directly on your system using Python and uv
  • Docker Installation - Run in containers with Docker Compose

docs.title: Technology Stack
docs.text:
• Backend: Django 5.2+
  • Database: SQLite
  • Frontend: Bootstrap 5, vanilla JavaScript
  • PDF Generation: Typst
  • Package Management: uv

docs.title: Deployment
docs.text: Production deployment guide for Plated.

docs.title: Pre-Deployment Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] Generate a strong SECRET_KEY
  • [ ] Set DEBUG=False
  • [ ] Configure ALLOWED_HOSTS with your domain
  • [ ] Set up HTTPS/SSL certificates
  • [ ] Configure backup strategy
  • [ ] Test all features in staging environment

docs.title: Generate SECRET_KEY
docs.text:
python -c "from django.core.management.utils import get_random_secret_key; print(get_random_secret_key())"

Store securely and set as environment variable.

docs.title: Django Settings
docs.text:
In production, configure these via environment variables:

SECRET_KEY=<your-generated-secret-key>
DEBUG=False
ALLOWED_HOSTS=yourdomain.com,www.yourdomain.com

docs.title: Option 1: Docker with Reverse Proxy
docs.text: Recommended for most deployments.

docs.title: 1. Set Up Nginx
docs.text:
Example nginx configuration:

server {
    listen 80;
    server_name yourdomain.com;
    return 301 https://$server_name$request_uri;
}

server {
    listen 443 ssl http2;
    server_name yourdomain.com;

    ssl_certificate /path/to/cert.pem;
    ssl_certificate_key /path/to/key.pem;

    client_max_body_size 10M;

    location / {
        proxy_pass http://localhost:8000;
        proxy_set_header Host $host;
        proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-Proto $scheme;
    }

    location /static/ {
        alias /path/to/staticfiles/;
        expires 30d;
        add_header Cache-Control "public, immutable";
    }

    location /media/ {
        alias /path/to/media/;
        expires 7d;
        add_header Cache-Control "public";
    }
}

docs.title: 2. Use Production WSGI Server
docs.text:
Update docker/Dockerfile CMD:

CMD ["gunicorn", "--bind", "0.0.0.0:8000", "--chdir", "src", "config.wsgi:application"]

Add to pyproject.toml:

dependencies = [
    "django>=5.2.8",
    "pillow>=12.0.0",
    "requests>=2.32.5",
    "gunicorn>=23.0.0",
]

docs.title: 3. Configure Docker Compose
docs.text:
Production docker/docker-compose.yml:

version: '3.8'

services:
  web:
    build:
      context: ..
      dockerfile: docker/Dockerfile
    restart: always
    ports:
      - "127.0.0.1:8000:8000"
    volumes:
      - db_data:/app/data
      - static_files:/app/staticfiles
      - media_files:/app/media
    environment:
      - SECRET_KEY=${SECRET_KEY}
      - DEBUG=False
      - ALLOWED_HOSTS=${ALLOWED_HOSTS}
      - DATABASE_URL=sqlite:////app/data/db.sqlite3
      - STATIC_ROOT=/app/staticfiles
      - MEDIA_ROOT=/app/media

volumes:
  db_data:
  static_files:
  media_files:

docs.title: 1. Set Up systemd Service
docs.text:
Create /etc/systemd/system/plated.service:

[Unit]
Description=Plated Recipe Manager
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=notify
User=www-data
Group=www-data
WorkingDirectory=/opt/plated
Environment="PATH=/opt/plated/.venv/bin"
Environment="SECRET_KEY=your-secret-key"
Environment="DEBUG=False"
Environment="ALLOWED_HOSTS=yourdomain.com"
ExecStart=/opt/plated/.venv/bin/gunicorn --bind 127.0.0.1:8000 --chdir src config.wsgi:application

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

docs.title: 2. Enable and Start Service
docs.text:
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable plated
sudo systemctl start plated

docs.title: 3. Configure Nginx
docs.text: Use the nginx configuration from Option 1.

docs.title: SQLite (Default)
docs.text:
Suitable for:

  • Small to medium deployments
  • Single-server setups
  • Low to moderate traffic

Limitations:

  • Limited concurrency
  • No network access
  • Single write operation at a time

docs.title: PostgreSQL (Production Alternative)
docs.text:
For high-traffic sites, consider PostgreSQL.

Update pyproject.toml:

dependencies = [
    "django>=5.2.8",
    "pillow>=12.0.0",
    "requests>=2.32.5",
    "psycopg[binary]>=3.2.0",
]

Update settings:

DATABASES = {
    'default': {
        'ENGINE': 'django.db.backends.postgresql',
        'NAME': os.environ.get('DB_NAME'),
        'USER': os.environ.get('DB_USER'),
        'PASSWORD': os.environ.get('DB_PASSWORD'),
        'HOST': os.environ.get('DB_HOST', 'localhost'),
        'PORT': os.environ.get('DB_PORT', '5432'),
    }
}

docs.title: Features
docs.text: Comprehensive guide to Plated's features.

docs.title: Creating Recipes
docs.text:
1. Click "Add Recipe" from the homepage

  2. Fill in recipe details:

    • Title (required)
    • Description
    • Number of servings
    • Prep time and wait time
    • Keywords (comma-separated)
    • Optional: URL, notes, special equipment

  3. Add ingredients with autocomplete suggestions

  4. Add preparation steps (supports Markdown)

  5. Upload recipe images

  6. Save

docs.title: Editing Recipes
docs.text: Click the Edit button on any recipe card or detail page.

docs.title: Smart Ingredient Input
docs.text: As you type ingredient names and units, autocomplete suggestions appear based on existing data. This helps maintain consistency across recipes.

docs.title: Markdown in Steps
docs.text:
Steps support Markdown formatting:

**Bold text** for emphasis
*Italic text* for notes
- Bullet lists
1. Numbered lists
[Links](https://example.com)

docs.title: Collections
docs.text: Group related recipes together.

docs.title: Creating Collections
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Collections
  2. Click "Create Collection"
  3. Add name, description, and recipes
  4. Save

Collections can contain any number of recipes.

docs.title: Exporting Recipes
docs.text: Click Export JSON on any recipe to download a JSON file containing all recipe data.

docs.title: Importing Recipes
docs.text:
1. Click Import Recipe from the homepage
  2. Upload a JSON file (previously exported)
  3. Review and confirm

docs.title: PDF Generation
docs.text: Generate beautifully formatted PDFs of your recipes.

docs.title: Export to PDF
docs.text: Click Download PDF on any recipe detail page. Requires Typst to be installed.

docs.title: PDF Format
docs.text:
PDFs include:

  • Recipe title and description
  • Ingredient list
  • Step-by-step instructions
  • Servings, prep time, wait time
  • Keywords and notes

docs.title: AI Recipe Extraction
docs.text: Extract recipe data from URLs using AI.

docs.title: Using AI Extraction
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Settings
  2. Configure AI settings (API key, model)
  3. Click AI Extract from homepage
  4. Enter a recipe URL
  5. Review extracted data
  6. Save as new recipe

Supported sources: Most recipe websites.

docs.title: Managing Ingredient Names
docs.text:
Keep ingredient names consistent:

  1. Navigate to Manage → Ingredient Names
  2. View all used ingredient names
  3. Rename to standardize (e.g., "tomatos" → "tomatoes")
  4. Changes apply to all recipes using that ingredient

docs.title: Managing Units
docs.text:
Standardize measurement units:

  1. Navigate to Manage → Units
  2. View all used units
  3. Rename to standardize (e.g., "tsp" → "teaspoon")
  4. Changes apply to all recipes using that unit

docs.title: Internationalization
docs.text: Plated supports multiple languages to make it accessible to users worldwide.

docs.title: Changing Language
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Settings
  2. Select your preferred language from the dropdown
  3. Click Save Language

The interface will immediately update to your chosen language.

docs.title: Available Languages
docs.text:
• English
  • German (Deutsch)

For information on adding new languages or contributing translations, see the Internationalization documentation.

docs.title: Changing Theme
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Settings
  2. Select from available themes:
    • Light
    • Dark
    • Auto (follows system preference)

Theme preference is saved in browser.

docs.title: Mobile Features
docs.text:
Plated is fully responsive and mobile-friendly:

  • Touch-optimized navigation
  • Readable text on small screens
  • Easy-to-tap buttons
  • PWA support (can be installed on mobile home screen)

docs.title: Scale Servings
docs.text:
On any recipe detail page:

  1. Click the servings adjuster
  2. Enter new serving count
  3. All ingredient amounts update automatically

docs.title: Admin Interface
docs.text:
Django admin provides advanced management:

  1. Navigate to /admin
  2. Log in with superuser credentials
  3. Access all models directly
  4. Bulk operations
  5. Advanced filtering

Useful for:

  • Bulk recipe imports
  • Data cleanup
  • User management (if enabled)
  • Viewing logs

docs.title: API Access
docs.text: For developers: Plated provides JSON export/import that can be automated.

docs.title: JSON Schema
docs.text: See src/recipeformat.txt for the complete schema specification.

docs.title: Programmatic Import
docs.text:
curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/import/ \
  -F "json_file=@recipe.json" \
  -H "X-CSRFToken: <token>"

CSRF token required for POST requests.

docs.title: Data Privacy
docs.text:
• All data stored locally in your SQLite database
  • No external services required (except optional AI extraction)
  • Full control over your recipe data
  • Export anytime in JSON format

docs.title: Internationalization (i18n)
docs.text: Plated supports multiple languages through Django's internationalization framework based on gettext.

docs.title: Changing Language
docs.text:
Users can select their preferred language from the settings:

  1. Navigate to Settings
  2. Select your language from the dropdown
  3. Click Save Language

The interface will immediately switch to the selected language.

docs.title: Supported Languages
docs.text:
Currently supported languages:

  • English (en)
  • German (de)

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Translation management requires GNU gettext tools:

Ubuntu/Debian:

sudo apt-get install gettext

macOS:

brew install gettext
brew link gettext --force

Windows: Download from GNU gettext website or use WSL.

docs.title: Adding a New Language
docs.text:
To add support for a new language:

  1. Add to settings

    Edit src/config/settings.py and add the language to the LANGUAGES list:

    LANGUAGES = [
    ("en", "English"),
    ("es", "Español"),
    ("fr", "Français"),
    ("de", "Deutsch"),
    ("it", "Italiano"),
    ("pt", "Português"),
    ("ja", "日本語"),  # Adding Japanese
]

  2. Generate message files

    From the src/ directory, run:

    uv run python src/plated/manage.py makemessages -l ja

    This creates src/locale/ja/LC_MESSAGES/django.po

  3. Translate strings

    Edit the generated .po file and translate the strings:

    msgid "Recipes"
msgstr "レシピ"

msgid "Settings"
msgstr "設定"

  4. Compile translations

    uv run python src/plated/manage.py compilemessages

    This creates django.mo binary files that Django uses.

  5. Test

    Restart the development server and select the new language in settings.

docs.title: Modifying Existing Translations
docs.text:
To update translations for an existing language:

  1. Update message files

    If you've added new translatable strings to the code, extract them:

    uv run python src/plated/manage.py makemessages -l es

    This updates src/locale/es/LC_MESSAGES/django.po with new strings.

  2. Edit translations

    Open the .po file and add/modify translations:

    #: templates/base.html:40
msgid "Recipes"
msgstr "Recetas"

#: recipes/views/settings.py:41
msgid "Language settings saved successfully!"
msgstr "¡Configuración de idioma guardada exitosamente!"

  3. Compile

    uv run python src/plated/manage.py compilemessages

  4. Test

    Refresh the browser to see changes (in production, restart may be needed).

docs.title: Updating All Languages
docs.text:
To update all language files at once:

uv run python src/plated/manage.py makemessages -a

Then edit each .po file and compile:

uv run python src/plated/manage.py compilemessages

docs.title: In Templates
docs.text:
Use the {% trans %} tag for simple strings:

{% load i18n %}
<h1>{% trans "Welcome to Plated" %}</h1>

For strings with variables, use {% blocktrans %}:

{% blocktrans count counter=list|length %}
There is {{ counter }} recipe
{% plural %}
There are {{ counter }} recipes
{% endblocktrans %}

docs.title: In Python Code
docs.text:
Use gettext() or its shortcuts:

from django.utils.translation import gettext as _

messages.success(request, _("Recipe saved successfully!"))

For lazy evaluation (in models, forms):

from django.utils.translation import gettext_lazy as _

class Recipe(models.Model):
    title = models.CharField(_("Title"), max_length=200)

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Context matters: Add context for ambiguous strings

    from django.utils.translation import pgettext

# "May" as month vs "may" as auxiliary verb
month = pgettext("month name", "May")

  2. Avoid concatenation: Don't split sentences

    ❌ Bad:

    _("Welcome") + " " + username

    ✅ Good:

    _("Welcome %(username)s") % {"username": username}

  3. Comments for translators: Add context when needed

    # Translators: This is shown when a recipe is successfully deleted
messages.success(request, _("Recipe deleted"))

  4. Test all languages: Verify translations display correctly

  5. Keep .po files in git: Track translation files in version control

docs.title: Translation Workflow
docs.text:
Recommended workflow for contributors:

  1. Developer adds translatable strings

    • Mark strings with {% trans %} or _()
    • Run makemessages to update .po files
    • Commit code and updated .po files

  2. Translator adds translations

    • Edit .po files
    • Run compilemessages to test locally
    • Commit translated .po files

  3. Deployment

    • Run compilemessages as part of deployment
    • .mo files should NOT be in git (generated files)

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Translations not showing:

  • Did you run compilemessages?
  • Did you restart the development server?
  • Is the language selected in settings?
  • Check browser language preferences don't override

Encoding errors:

Ensure .po files use UTF-8 encoding:

file -i locale/es/LC_MESSAGES/django.po
# Should show: charset=utf-8

Missing strings:

If a string isn't being picked up:

  1. Verify the string is wrapped with {% trans %} or _()
  2. Run makemessages again
  3. Check the .po file was updated
  4. Recompile with compilemessages

docs.title: Advanced: JavaScript Translations
docs.text:
For translating strings in JavaScript files:

  1. Mark strings in JS

    Create a JavaScript catalog view in urls.py:

    from django.views.i18n import JavaScriptCatalog

urlpatterns = [
    path('jsi18n/', JavaScriptCatalog.as_view(), name='javascript-catalog'),
]

  2. Include in template

    <script src="{% url 'javascript-catalog' %}"></script>

  3. Use in JavaScript

    const message = gettext("Recipe saved!");

  4. Extract and compile

    JavaScript strings are extracted with makemessages -d djangojs

docs.title: File Structure
docs.text:
Translation files are organized as:

src/
├── locale/
│   ├── es/
│   │   └── LC_MESSAGES/
│   │       ├── django.po      # Editable translation file
│   │       └── django.mo      # Compiled (generated)
│   ├── fr/
│   │   └── LC_MESSAGES/
│   │       ├── django.po
│   │       └── django.mo
│   └── ...

docs.title: Contributing Translations
docs.text:
Contributions of new translations are welcome!

  1. Fork the repository
  2. Add or update translations following the guide above
  3. Test locally
  4. Submit a pull request with:
    • Updated .po files
    • Updated LANGUAGES in settings.py (if new language)
    • DO NOT include .mo files (these are generated)

Native speakers are especially encouraged to contribute!

docs.title: Docker Installation
docs.text: Run Plated using Docker and Docker Compose.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Docker
  • Docker Compose

docs.title: 1. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/yourusername/plated.git
cd plated

docs.title: 2. Build and Start
docs.text:
cd docker
docker-compose up -d

The application will be available at http://localhost:8000

docs.title: 3. Create Admin User
docs.text: docker-compose exec web python src/manage.py createsuperuser

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Customize settings in docker/docker-compose.yml or create docker/.env:

Variable Default Description SECRET_KEY (dev key) Change in production! DEBUG False Enable debug mode ALLOWED_HOSTS localhost,127.0.0.1 Allowed hostnames PORT 8000 Host port mapping DATABASE_URL sqlite:////app/data/db.sqlite3 Database URL (SQLite or PostgreSQL) STATIC_ROOT /app/staticfiles Static files directory MEDIA_ROOT /app/media Media uploads directory

docs.title: Example .env File
docs.text:
SECRET_KEY=your-production-secret-key
DEBUG=False
ALLOWED_HOSTS=example.com,www.example.com
PORT=8000

docs.title: Data Persistence
docs.text:
Three Docker volumes persist your data:

  • db_data - SQLite database
  • static_files - CSS, JavaScript, images
  • media_files - User-uploaded recipe images

docs.title: View Logs
docs.text: docker-compose logs -f

docs.title: Stop Application
docs.text: docker-compose down

docs.title: Restart Application
docs.text: docker-compose restart

docs.title: Run Management Commands
docs.text:
# Run migrations
docker-compose exec web python src/manage.py migrate

# Collect static files
docker-compose exec web python src/manage.py collectstatic

# Seed sample data
docker-compose exec web python src/manage.py seed_db

docs.title: Backup Database
docs.text: docker-compose exec web cat /app/data/db.sqlite3 > backup.sqlite3

docs.title: Restore Database
docs.text:
cat backup.sqlite3 | docker-compose exec -T web tee /app/data/db.sqlite3 > /dev/null
docker-compose restart

docs.title: Docker Image Details
docs.text:
The Dockerfile includes:

  • Python 3.12 slim base image
  • uv package manager
  • Typst for PDF generation
  • All Python dependencies
  • Automatic migrations on startup

docs.title: Pull Latest Changes
docs.text:
git pull origin main
cd docker
docker-compose build --no-cache
docker-compose up -d

docs.title: Run Migrations After Update
docs.text: docker-compose exec web python src/manage.py migrate

docs.title: Permission Errors
docs.text: docker-compose exec web chown -R $(id -u):$(id -g) /app/data /app/media /app/staticfiles

docs.title: Database Locked
docs.text: SQLite has limited concurrency. Consider PostgreSQL for high-traffic deployments.

docs.title: Static Files Not Loading
docs.text:
docker-compose exec web python src/manage.py collectstatic --noinput
docker-compose restart

docs.title: Container Won't Start
docs.text:
Check logs for errors:

docker-compose logs web

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• See Deployment for production configuration
  • See the detailed Docker guide for advanced topics

docs.title: Native Installation
docs.text: Install Plated directly on your system using Python and uv.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.12 or later
  • uv package manager
  • Typst (optional, for PDF generation)

docs.title: Installing uv
docs.text:
macOS/LinuxWindows 
curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh

powershell -c "irm https://astral.sh/uv/install.ps1 | iex"

docs.title: Installing Typst
docs.text:
macOSLinuxWindows 
brew install typst

# Download latest release from GitHub
curl -LO https://github.com/typst/typst/releases/latest/download/typst-x86_64-unknown-linux-musl.tar.xz
tar -xf typst-x86_64-unknown-linux-musl.tar.xz
sudo mv typst-*/typst /usr/local/bin/

# Download from https://github.com/typst/typst/releases
# Extract and add to PATH

docs.title: 1. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/yourusername/plated.git
cd plated

docs.title: 2. Install Dependencies
docs.text:
uv sync

This creates a virtual environment and installs all required packages.

docs.title: 3. Run Migrations
docs.text: uv run python src/manage.py migrate

docs.title: 4. Create Static Directories
docs.text: mkdir -p src/media src/staticfiles src/logs

docs.title: 5. Collect Static Files
docs.text: uv run python src/manage.py collectstatic --noinput

docs.title: 6. Create Admin User
docs.text:
uv run python src/manage.py createsuperuser

Follow the prompts to set username, email, and password.

docs.title: 7. Start Development Server
docs.text:
uv run python src/manage.py runserver

Access the application at http://localhost:8000

docs.title: Optional: Seed Sample Data
docs.text: uv run python src/manage.py seed_db

docs.title: Run Tests
docs.text: uv run pytest

docs.title: Type Checking
docs.text: uv run mypy src/

docs.title: Code Formatting
docs.text:
# Check formatting
uv run ruff format --check src/

# Apply formatting
uv run ruff format src/

docs.title: Linting
docs.text: uv run ruff check src/

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Create a .env file in the project root (optional):

SECRET_KEY=your-secret-key-here
DEBUG=True
ALLOWED_HOSTS=localhost,127.0.0.1

# Database configuration (SQLite by default)
DATABASE_URL=sqlite:///path/to/db.sqlite3

# Or for PostgreSQL:
# DATABASE_URL=postgresql://user:password@localhost:5432/plated

STATIC_ROOT=/path/to/staticfiles
MEDIA_ROOT=/path/to/media

See settings.py for all available options.

Note: The old DATABASE_PATH variable is still supported for backward compatibility, but DATABASE_URL is preferred.

docs.title: Port Already in Use
docs.text:
Run on a different port:

uv run python src/manage.py runserver 8080

docs.title: Static Files Not Loading
docs.text:
Ensure you've run collectstatic:

uv run python src/manage.py collectstatic --noinput

docs.title: Database Locked
docs.text: Only one process can access SQLite at a time. Stop other instances or use a different database for production.

docs.text:
